conclusion: Analyze forces and use conservation of energy to find speed and tension.
Determine electric and gravitational forces.
Electric force is \( F_e = qE \).
Gravitational force is \( F_g = mg \).
Analyze equilibrium at point A.
Sphere is in equilibrium at point A, net force is zero.
Forces acting: tension \( T \), gravitational force \( mg \), electric force \( qE \).
Angle between string and vertical is \( \theta = 30^\circ \).
Horizontal component of electric force balances horizontal component of tension.
Vertical component of electric force balances vertical component of tension minus weight.
Horizontal component of electric force is \( qE \sin 30^\circ \).
Vertical component of electric force is \( qE \cos 30^\circ \).
Vertical component of tension is \( T \cos 30^\circ \).
Vertical component of weight is \( mg \).
Equation \( qE \cos 30^\circ = mg \).
Equation \( qE \sin 30^\circ = T \sin 30^\circ \).
Electric field \( E = \frac{2mg}{q \sqrt{3}} \).
Tension \( T = \frac{4mg}{\sqrt{3}} \).
Determine speed at lowest point C.
Potential energy difference between B and C is \( \frac{mgL}{q \sqrt{3}} \).
Kinetic energy at C equals potential energy difference.
Equation \( \frac{1}{2} mv^2 = \frac{mgL}{q \sqrt{3}} \).
Speed \( v = \sqrt{\frac{2gL}{q \sqrt{3}}} \).
Determine tension at lowest point C.
